title: Poster, Oil and Water Do Not Mix, 2010
title_raw: Oil and Water Do Not Mix
medium: Screenprint with oil culled from the Gulf of Mexico, sand, and extender base on white wove paper
signed: In graphite, lower right:  Anthony Burrill
provenance: September 2012: acquired by Museum directly from the designer, Anthony Burrill
description: Screenprinted (artist's proof) poster with the text "OIL & WATER" and a rectangular block with a  wavy line suggesting water printed in brown oil.  White paper ground shows through the block to form the text "DO NOT MIX" "GULF OF MEXICO - 2010".
justification:
In the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill (also known as the BP oil spill) in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, designer and graphic artist Anthony Burrill was approached by Tom Galle and Cecilia Azcarate Isturiz, the creative team at the innovative communications agency, Happiness Brussels. Galle and Isturiz asked Burrill to design a poster that would be printed with oil from the spill. Burrill was drawn to the opportunity to produce something positive from such a disaster. A few days later, Burrill submitted his design.
Isturiz and Galle flew to Louisiana to capture oil from the spill that had leeched into the sandy beaches of the coastline. Upon their arrival, they found the entire beach cordoned off but, when BP security personnel left for lunch, the team sneaked past the barriers and filled their buckets with the crude saturated sand. The oil was brought to Purple Monkey Design, a commercial print shop based in New Orleans, where the oil and sand were mixed with extender base and a limited edition of 200 screenprints were produced. 
Burrill’s poster design features a simple and straightforward slogan: OIL & WATER DO NOT MIX. The text is capitalized and in block lettering. Isturiz, Galle, and Burrill launched a website through which the posters were sold, with all proceeds benefiting the Coalition to Restore Coastal Louisiana (CRCL). The posters sold out within days, and the creative team received a blitz of media attention. A short film about the process was produced by Happiness Brussels.
Approximately 20 additional copies of the poster were printed as proofs, of which this one is being offered to the museum as a gift by the designer. An impression of this poster was included in the exhibition Graphic Design: Now in Production.
label_text: In response to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010, designer Anthony Burrill teamed up with Azcarate and Galle to design a poster to raise money for recovery efforts. Azcarate and Galle flew to Louisiana to capture oil from the spill. They brought oil and sand to the print shop Purple Monkey Design, where it was mixed with extender base to create an ink that could pass smoothly through a screen. The printed oil produces a shimmering, golden color.
